title: How to Do a Butterfly Sit Ups (and Variations) for a Strong Core

steps.title: Sit on the floor and press your feet together.
steps.content: Sit on the floor and press your feet together. Find a comfortable place where you can sit and work out, like a yoga mat or padded gym floor. Press the soles of your feet together, keeping your knees bent to the sides, like butterfly wings. [2] X Research source With traditional sit-ups or crunches, your feet are usually planted on the ground to start. With butterfly sit-ups, your feet are pressed together at the soles. Your heels will be at least 1 ft (12 in) or so in front of your hips. If you're not able to press your feet together quite yet, practice stretching and opening up your hips every day so you become more flexible. The more flexible you are, the easier the exercise will be. [3] X Expert Source Souad Gharib Exercise & Wellness Specialist Expert Interview. 8 July 2021.

steps.title: Place a rolled up towel behind you to support your back.
steps.content: Place a rolled up towel behind you to support your back. Butterfly sit-ups can be a bit strange at first, and may be tough on your back. Roll up a gym towel and set it directly behind you, so your lower back stays supported during the exercise. [4] X Research source Any type of pad works for this, as long as it cushions your back in the process.

steps.title: Cross your arms across your chest.
steps.content: Cross your arms across your chest. Bring your right hand to your left shoulder and your left hand to your right shoulder, creating an “X” with your arms. Hold your arms in place for the entire sit-up. [5] X Research source This arm position is a little easier for beginners—this way, you don’t have to worry about your arms.

steps.title: Lean backward until your back touches the ground.
steps.content: Lean backward until your back touches the ground. Pretend you’re doing an ordinary sit-up, leaning yourself down to the floor and onto your towel. [6] X Research source Don’t worry if you can’t completely lay down—just lean your torso as far back as you can. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Tighten your abdominal muscles and sit up to finish the rep.
steps.content: Tighten your abdominal muscles and sit up to finish the rep. Lift yourself back up to your starting position. Lengthen your spine as you sit up, keeping your lower back slightly curved. Keep your feet pressed together as you complete the rep. [8] X Research source Some people prefer to lean forward when they finish a rep, while others don’t straighten their back all the way.

steps.title: Do 2-3 sets of 10-12 reps.
steps.content: Do 2-3 sets of 10-12 reps. Perform 10 butterfly sit-ups at a time, giving yourself 30-40 seconds between each set. Start with 2 sets if you’re a beginner, then gradually work your way up to 3 sets. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Do a butterfly sit-up with your arms out straight.
steps.content: Do a butterfly sit-up with your arms out straight. Lie on your back with your legs in the butterfly position, extending your arms straight above your head. Tighten your core muscles and lift yourself up, swinging your arms forward while you sit up. Follow your body’s momentum as you sit up, guiding your arms forward until you touch your toes. Then, lie back down with your arms extended above your head. [10] X Research source The exercise is a little more challenging when you keep your arms straight. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Lift a medicine ball during your workout.
steps.content: Lift a medicine ball during your workout. Sit in the butterfly position and hold a medicine ball with both hands. Lie down with your back flat on the ground, bringing the medicine ball up and over your head. Sit up, tightening your abdominals as you swing the medicine ball over your head and in front of your feet. [12] X Research source Choose a medicine ball that you comfortably lift for multiple reps. You don’t want to strain yourself! [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can also lift a dumbbell instead of a medicine ball. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Try basic sit-ups with a resistance band if butterfly sit-ups are too challenging.
steps.content: Try basic sit-ups with a resistance band if butterfly sit-ups are too challenging. Wrap a long, stretchy resistance band around your feet and grip the loose ends with your hands. Hold onto the band while you do your sit-ups—it’ll make it a little easier for you to lift yourself up during the exercise. [15] X Research source
